questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with a recent history of acute myocardial infarction is being monitored for inflammatory markers to assess the resolution of inflammation. The patient’s C-reactive protein (CRP) levels were elevated immediately post-infarction and are now being rechecked daily. Understanding CRP kinetics is important in interpreting these results. What is the half-life of CRP?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The half-life of C-reactive protein (CRP) is approximately 18 hours , making it a reliable marker to monitor the progression or resolution of inflammation.
  • ➤ 18 hours

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with chronic fatigue and signs of liver dysfunction. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes and mild hyperbilirubinemia. A detailed metabolic panel suggests an issue with amino acid metabolism. Given these findings, which enzyme activity that requires pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme is most likely deficient in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Transamination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transamination reactions, which require pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme, are essential for amino acid metabolism and are particularly active in the liver. Deficiency in these reactions can lead to elevated liver enzymes and impaired amino acid metabolism, as seen in liver dysfunction.
  • ➤ Transamination reactions, which require pyridoxal phosphate (PLP) as a coenzyme, are essential for amino acid metabolism and are particularly active in the liver.
  • ➤ Transamination
  • ➤ Deficiency in these reactions can lead to elevated liver enzymes and impaired amino acid metabolism, as seen in liver dysfunction.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with Parkinson’s disease presents to the clinic with concerns about recent behavioral changes. He reports an uncontrollable urge to gamble, which has led to significant financial losses. He also mentions increased impulsivity, such as binge eating and excessive shopping, over the past few months. He has been on a stable medication regimen, including a drug prescribed to manage his motor symptoms. Which of the following medications is most likely responsible for these side effects?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pramipexole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dopamine agonists like pramipexole and ropinirole are effective for managing motor symptoms in Parkinson’s disease but carry a significant risk of impulse control disorders, necessitating careful monitoring and patient education.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms describes how Toll-like receptors (TLRs) recognize bacterial components and stimulate an immune response?

options.label: C
options.text: Transcription of nuclear factor mediated by NF-κB, which recruits cytokines

questions.correct_answer: C. Transcription of nuclear factor mediated by NF-κB, which recruits cytokines
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Toll-like receptors (TLRs) activate the NF-κB pathway upon recognizing pathogen-associated molecules, leading to the transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines essential for the immune response.
  • ➤ Toll-like receptors (TLRs) activate the NF-κB pathway upon recognizing pathogen-associated molecules, leading to the transcription of pro-inflammatory cytokines essential for the immune response.

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered an effective method for emergency contraception?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Danazol is not a method for emergency contraception. Instead, emergency contraception includes methods like combined high-dose estrogen-progestin pills, copper IUDs, and Mifepristone (RU486).
  • ➤ Danazol is not a method for emergency contraception. Instead, emergency contraception includes methods like combined high-dose estrogen-progestin pills, copper IUDs, and Mifepristone (RU486).

  • ➤ The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with dysphagia and chest pain that worsens with stress and eating. He describes the sensation as food getting stuck in his chest. The physician suspects a motility disorder and orders an investigation to confirm the diagnosis. Identify the investigation based on the image provided:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Esophageal manometry

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Esophageal manometry is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing esophageal motility disorders such as achalasia and diffuse esophageal spasm.
  • ➤ Esophageal manometry is the gold standard investigation for diagnosing esophageal motility disorders such as achalasia and diffuse esophageal spasm.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a characteristic feature of Wegener’s granulomatosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener’s) is a small-to-medium vessel vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas, crescentic glomerulonephritis, and association with c-ANCA. It does not typically involve large vessels, distinguishing it from Vasculitis that affect larger vessels.
  • ➤ Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (Wegener’s) is a small-to-medium vessel vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas, crescentic glomerulonephritis, and association with c-ANCA.
  • ➤ It does not typically involve large vessels, distinguishing it from Vasculitis that affect larger vessels.

questions.text: A 40-year-old gardener presents with multiple nodular lesions on his forearm that started at the site of a thorn prick and have spread along the lymphatic channels in an ascending pattern. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for this pattern of cutaneous lesions?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sporotrichoid pattern, where lesions spread along lymphatic channels, is a hallmark of infection by Sporothrix schenckii , particularly in individuals with recent exposure to soil or plant material.
  • ➤ Sporothrix schenckii

questions.text: A patient who was recently started on haloperidol presents with fever, confusion, muscle rigidity, and autonomic instability. Labs show elevated CPK (1500 U/L), leukocytosis (15,000/μL), and elevated liver enzymes. His temperature is 39.5°C. Which combination of treatments would be most appropriate?
questions.correct_answer: B. Dantrolene + supportive care + stop haloperidol
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Dantrolene + supportive care + stop haloperidol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) is a serious reaction associated with antipsychotic use, characterized by fever, rigidity, altered mental status, and autonomic dysfunction. Treatment includes discontinuing the antipsychotic medication, providing supportive care, and considering the use of a medication like dantrolene , dopamine agonists such as amantadine and bromocriptine to address the dopamine dysregulation associated with NMS.
  • ➤ Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome (NMS) is a serious reaction associated with antipsychotic use, characterized by fever, rigidity, altered mental status, and autonomic dysfunction.
  • ➤ Treatment includes discontinuing the antipsychotic medication, providing supportive care, and considering the use of a medication like dantrolene , dopamine agonists such as amantadine and bromocriptine to address the dopamine dysregulation associated with NMS.
  • ➤ dantrolene

questions.text: Which of the following structures is developed from the paraxial mesoderm?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Skeletal muscles

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The paraxial mesoderm plays a crucial role in developing skeletal muscles.
  • ➤ The paraxial mesoderm plays a crucial role in developing skeletal muscles.

questions.text: In neonatal resuscitation, which of the following is correct regarding the components of the NRP (Neonatal Resuscitation Program) protocol?

options.label: A
options.text: Temperature should be maintained between 37.0°C and 38.0°C

options.label: B
options.text: The preferred chest compression to ventilation ratio is 3:1

options.label: C
options.text: The "head tilt-chin lift" position is recommended for airway management

options.label: D
options.text: Epinephrine should be administered with a compression rate of 60:30 (compression to ventilation ratio)

questions.correct_answer: B. The preferred chest compression to ventilation ratio is 3:1
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In neonatal resuscitation, the NRP protocol includes specific guidelines for temperature control (36.5°C to 37.5°C), airway management using the sniffing position, a 3:1 compression to ventilation ratio, and the use of drugs such as epinephrine when necessary.
  • ➤ In neonatal resuscitation, the NRP protocol includes specific guidelines for temperature control (36.5°C to 37.5°C), airway management using the sniffing position, a 3:1 compression to ventilation ratio, and the use of drugs such as epinephrine when necessary.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a 5-day history of a spreading rash. She reports that it began as a small red spot on her thigh that has expanded progressively and now measures approximately 15 cm in diameter. The lesion is not painful but feels warm to the touch. On examination, you observe a target-like lesion as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Erythema migrans

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Erythema migrans is a hallmark rash of Lyme disease, characterized by an expanding bullseye-like appearance. It typically appears days to weeks after a tick bite and is warm but non-painful, expanding over time without systemic symptoms in early cases.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining a stab wound to his left flank during a street brawl. On examination, he has active bleeding from the wound site, and his urine sample shows hematuria. Based on the location of the injury, which of the following organs is least likely to have been injured?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Inferior vena cava

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inferior vena cava is positioned more toward the midline and the right side of the body, making it less likely to be injured in left flank trauma. In left-sided injuries, structures such as the spleen , left kidney , and stomach are at greater risk.
  • ➤ Inferior vena cava is positioned more toward the midline and the right side of the body, making it less likely to be injured in left flank trauma.
  • ➤ Inferior vena cava
  • ➤ In left-sided injuries, structures such as the spleen , left kidney , and stomach are at greater risk.
  • ➤ spleen
  • ➤ left kidney
  • ➤ stomach

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is undergoing evaluation for an autoimmune disorder. The physician explains that certain areas in the body are protected from immune system attacks due to their "immunologically privileged" status, helping to prevent inflammation and damage. Which of the following sites is considered immunologically privileged?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Seminiferous tubule, spermatozoa, lens protein, placenta and the fetus are the immunologically privileged site. Brain is no longer considered immunologically privileged.
  • ➤ Seminiferous tubule, spermatozoa, lens protein, placenta and the fetus are the immunologically privileged site.
  • ➤ Brain is no longer considered immunologically privileged.

questions.text: Which hormone is primarily responsible for acting on the post-ovulatory endometrium?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Progesterone is the hormone responsible for converting the post-ovulatory endometrium into a secretory phase, preparing it for potential implantation.
  • ➤ Progesterone is the hormone responsible for converting the post-ovulatory endometrium into a secretory phase, preparing it for potential implantation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old researcher studying cell death mechanisms notes that a specific form of programmed cell death involves activation of caspase-1 and results in the release of pro-inflammatory cytokines such as IL-1β and IL-18. Which form of cell death is the researcher most likely observing?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyroptosis is a caspase-1-dependent form of programmed cell death that releases pro-inflammatory cytokines, specifically IL-1β and IL-18, to promote an immune response. It is distinct from other forms of cell death, such as apoptosis, necrosis, and autophagy.
  • ➤ Pyroptosis is a caspase-1-dependent form of programmed cell death that releases pro-inflammatory cytokines, specifically IL-1β and IL-18, to promote an immune response.
  • ➤ It is distinct from other forms of cell death, such as apoptosis, necrosis, and autophagy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man, who had recently recovered from tetanus without any residual symptoms, dies in a road traffic accident on his way home. His body remains at the accident site under a high ambient temperature of 40°C for around 6 hours before being taken to the morgue. At the morgue, his rectal temperature is noted to be 39°C. What is the most probable reason for the elevated body temperature postmortem?

options.label: A
options.text: Residual neuromuscular excitation from tetanus, causing elevated temperature after death

options.label: B
options.text: High ambient temperature slowing the body's cooling process

options.label: C
options.text: Muscle contractions after death due to previous tetanus infection

options.label: D
options.text: Rapid decomposition due to prior tetanus infection

questions.correct_answer: B. High ambient temperature slowing the body's cooling process
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) High ambient temperature slowing the body's cooling process

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postmortem body temperature is significantly influenced by ambient conditions. When a body is exposed to high environmental temperatures, cooling is delayed, which can result in an elevated temperature several hours after death.
  • ➤ Postmortem body temperature is significantly influenced by ambient conditions.
  • ➤ When a body is exposed to high environmental temperatures, cooling is delayed, which can result in an elevated temperature several hours after death.

questions.text: A person is able to abduct his arm, internally rotate it, place the back of hand on lumbosacral joint, but is not able to lift it from back. What is etiology?

options.label: C
options.text: Long head of biceps tendon tear

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Subscapularis tendon tear

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subscapularis tendon tear directly impacts the ability to internally rotate the arm and perform movements such as lifting the hand from behind the back. The subscapularis is a key player in this motion, and a tear in its tendon would result in the specific functional limitation.
  • ➤ Subscapularis tendon tear directly impacts the ability to internally rotate the arm and perform movements such as lifting the hand from behind the back.
  • ➤ The subscapularis is a key player in this motion, and a tear in its tendon would result in the specific functional limitation.

questions.text: In the diagnostic evaluation of Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT), both impedance plethysmography and leg scanning after injecting 125I-fibrinogen are performed simultaneously. What is the primary outcome of using these tests together?
questions.correct_answer: B. Increasing the negative predictive value
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increasing the negative predictive value

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In parallel testing, combining multiple diagnostic tests increases sensitivity and negative predictive value, making a negative result more reliable in ruling out a condition like DVT.
  • ➤ In parallel testing, combining multiple diagnostic tests increases sensitivity and negative predictive value, making a negative result more reliable in ruling out a condition like DVT.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with recurrent deep vein thrombosis (DVT) requires a blood sample for coagulation testing. Which anticoagulant is preferred?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For coagulation testing, 3.2% trisodium citrate is the anticoagulant of choice due to its ability to prevent clotting by chelating calcium without significantly interfering with the measurement of coagulation factors.
  • ➤ For coagulation testing, 3.2% trisodium citrate is the anticoagulant of choice due to its ability to prevent clotting by chelating calcium without significantly interfering with the measurement of coagulation factors.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman at 36 weeks of pregnancy is found to have a fetus in a transverse lie on ultrasound. Amniotic fluid levels are within normal range, the placenta appears normal, and no fetal anomalies are identified. Her two previous deliveries were uncomplicated vaginal births. What is the most appropriate next step in management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a fetus in a transverse lie at 36 weeks without other complications, external cephalic version (ECV) is the most appropriate intervention to attempt turning the fetus to a head-down position, potentially avoiding cesarean delivery.
  • ➤ For a fetus in a transverse lie at 36 weeks without other complications, external cephalic version (ECV) is the most appropriate intervention to attempt turning the fetus to a head-down position, potentially avoiding cesarean delivery.

questions.text: A forensic examiner is tasked with analyzing a preserved set of clothing from a 4-month-old case, with suspicion regarding the presence of seminal stains on the fabric. Considering the potential degradation of the sample due to age, which of the following biochemical tests would be the most reliable to establish the presence of semen?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For identifying aged seminal stains, the Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) test is the preferred biochemical method due to its stability and reliability in older samples.
  • ➤ For identifying aged seminal stains, the Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) test is the preferred biochemical method due to its stability and reliability in older samples.
  • ➤ Creatine phosphokinase (CPK) test

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of frequent falls, particularly backward, stiffness while standing, and difficulty maintaining posture. He also reports mild difficulty with upward gaze but denies tremors or other significant motor issues. Neurological examination reveals axial rigidity, a wide-based gait, and impaired voluntary vertical eye movements. MRI of the brain is taken and shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Progressive supranuclear palsy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Backward falls with vertical gaze palsy and axial rigidity strongly suggest progressive supranuclear palsy . Early imaging (e.g., hummingbird sign on MRI) helps differentiate PSP from other neurodegenerative disorders.
  • ➤ progressive supranuclear palsy

questions.text: Assertion and Reason Assertion (A): ‘Second sight’ is seen in cases of cortical cataract. Reason (R): Change in the refractive index of the nucleus causes index myopia, improving near vision.

options.label: A
options.text: Both statements are true, and the reason explains the assertion.

options.label: B
options.text: Both statements are true, but the reason does not explain the assertion.

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is true, but the reason is false.

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is false, but the reason is true.

questions.correct_answer: D. Assertion is false, but the reason is true.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Assertion is false, but the reason is true.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ "Second sight" is associated with nuclear cataracts due to a myopic shift from changes in the refractive index of the nucleus, not cortical cataracts.
  • ➤ "Second sight" is associated with nuclear cataracts due to a myopic shift from changes in the refractive index of the nucleus, not cortical cataracts.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman experiences recurrent sharp lower abdominal pain lasting for 2–3 days each month, typically occurring about 14 days before her menstrual period. What is the most likely cause of her symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mittelschmerz, or mid-cycle ovulatory pain, should be suspected in women with recurrent sharp or crampy lower abdominal pain occurring approximately 14 days before menses. This pain is typically short-lived and associated with the ovulation phase of the menstrual cycle.
  • ➤ Mittelschmerz, or mid-cycle ovulatory pain, should be suspected in women with recurrent sharp or crampy lower abdominal pain occurring approximately 14 days before menses.
  • ➤ This pain is typically short-lived and associated with the ovulation phase of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with a long-standing history of hearing loss and tinnitus. She reports a recent increase in her symptoms, and MRI reveals bilateral masses at the cerebellopontine angle. Histological examination of the biopsy specimen from one of the masses as shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this type of tumor?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Schwannomas are benign tumors of the nerve sheath, commonly associated with cranial nerves, especially cranial nerve VIII. They are frequently benign and may be associated with NF2, particularly when bilateral. The presence of Verocay bodies is a characteristic histological feature, and malignancy is rare.
  • ➤ Schwannomas are benign tumors of the nerve sheath, commonly associated with cranial nerves, especially cranial nerve VIII.
  • ➤ They are frequently benign and may be associated with NF2, particularly when bilateral. The presence of Verocay bodies is a characteristic histological feature, and malignancy is rare.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with an ovarian mass identified on ultrasound. Histological examination reveals an adenofibroma of the ovary with nests of transitional cells in the epithelial component. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brenner tumors of the ovary are adenofibromas with a distinctive epithelial component comprising nests of transitional (urothelial-like) cells. This feature is essential for differentiating Brenner tumors from other ovarian neoplasms.
  • ➤ Brenner tumors of the ovary are adenofibromas with a distinctive epithelial component comprising nests of transitional (urothelial-like) cells.
  • ➤ This feature is essential for differentiating Brenner tumors from other ovarian neoplasms.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department after a blunt trauma to the perineal region sustained while straddling a bicycle. He is experiencing swelling and bruising in the perineum and scrotum, and physical examination reveals blood pooling in the area. There is suspicion of a rupture of the penile urethra. In this scenario, extravasation of blood is least likely to extend into which of the following spaces?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ischiorectal fossa is typically spared from extravasation of blood following penile urethral rupture due to its separation by fascial layers and the perineal membrane.
  • ➤ The ischiorectal fossa is typically spared from extravasation of blood following penile urethral rupture due to its separation by fascial layers and the perineal membrane.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman with a history of epilepsy is receiving valproate for seizure control. Her neurologist decides to add carbamazepine to her treatment plan to improve seizure management. After several weeks, she returns to the clinic with adverse effects. Which of the following adverse effects is most likely to increase when carbamazepine is added to valproate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hepatotoxicity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of valproate and carbamazepine increases the risk of hepatotoxicity due to enzyme induction by carbamazepine, leading to the formation of a hepatotoxic valproate metabolite. Close monitoring of liver function tests is essential for patients on this combination.
  • ➤ The combination of valproate and carbamazepine increases the risk of hepatotoxicity due to enzyme induction by carbamazepine, leading to the formation of a hepatotoxic valproate metabolite.
  • ➤ Close monitoring of liver function tests is essential for patients on this combination.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of weight loss, recurrent diarrhea, and painful blistering rashes that evolve into pruritic, crusty lesions and then resolve spontaneously. On physical examination, there is bronze-colored induration and scaling rash involving the perioral region, perineum, and lower extremities. Laboratory findings: Hemoglobin: 10.1 g/dL Glucose: 236 mg/dL Serum glucagon: Elevated Serum zinc: Low Abdominal ultrasound reveals a 3-cm, solid, well-defined mass in the head of the pancreas. This patient’s tumor is most likely derived from which of the following types of cells?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pancreatic α-cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucagonoma, a tumor of pancreatic α-cells, should be considered in patients with hyperglycemia, necrolytic migratory erythema, and systemic symptoms like weight loss and diarrhea. The addition of serum glucagon and zinc levels can provide diagnostic clues for challenging cases.

questions.text: A forensic expert is examining a set of skeletal remains discovered at an archaeological site. The mandible is relatively well preserved. The focus is on determining the sex of the individual based on the mandible. Which of the following features would most likely indicate a male mandible compared to a female mandible?

options.label: A
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: B
options.text: Round Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: C
options.text: Square Chin, more obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

options.label: D
options.text: Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, smaller body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

questions.correct_answer: A. Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Square Chin, less obtuse angle of mandible, greater body height at symphysis, greater breadth of ascending ramus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Male and female mandible
  • ➤ Male and female mandible

questions.text: A 68-year-old man underwent hemicolectomy for adenocarcinoma of the colon. Post-surgery, he developed respiratory distress with a significant drop in pO2 levels. Despite being intubated and receiving 100% oxygen, a chest X-ray shows diffuse opacities in all lung fields. A transbronchial lung biopsy reveals the findings shown in the image below. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Activation of coagulation pathways leading to microthrombi formation

options.label: B
options.text: Inhalation of gastric contents causing inflammation

options.label: D
options.text: Release of fibrogenic cytokines by macrophages

questions.correct_answer: C. Injury to alveolar capillary endothelium
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ARDS is primarily caused by injury to the alveolar-capillary barrier, leading to increased permeability, pulmonary edema, and hyaline membrane formation. This condition often follows major surgery or trauma and is marked by severe hypoxemia and diffuse opacities on imaging.
  • ➤ ARDS is primarily caused by injury to the alveolar-capillary barrier, leading to increased permeability, pulmonary edema, and hyaline membrane formation.
  • ➤ This condition often follows major surgery or trauma and is marked by severe hypoxemia and diffuse opacities on imaging.

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presents with complaints of pain and swelling in the perineal area, with associated difficulty in walking and sitting. She reports a history of multiple sexual partners. On physical examination, there is a tender swelling with redness on the labia. Based on the clinical presentation and image findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bartholin abscess should be suspected in a female patient presenting with painful, tender swelling in the perineal area, particularly if associated with redness and difficulty in walking or sitting.
  • ➤ Bartholin abscess should be suspected in a female patient presenting with painful, tender swelling in the perineal area, particularly if associated with redness and difficulty in walking or sitting.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is not characteristic of acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is typically associated with decreased C3 levels, hypertension, elevated creatinine, and positive streptococcal titers (ASO or anti-DNAase B) following a recent streptococcal infection.
  • ➤ Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis is typically associated with decreased C3 levels, hypertension, elevated creatinine, and positive streptococcal titers (ASO or anti-DNAase B) following a recent streptococcal infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effect associated with endothelin-1?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bronchodilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endothelin-1 is a potent vasoconstrictor that reduces GFR and has a positive inotropic effect on cardiac muscle but does not cause bronchodilation.
  • ➤ Endothelin-1 is a potent vasoconstrictor that reduces GFR and has a positive inotropic effect on cardiac muscle but does not cause bronchodilation.

questions.text: A mother brings her male infant to the pediatrician with right-sided scrotal swelling, which is maximum at night, but disappears when the child wakes up in the morning. The swelling is soft and shows transillumination. What will be the management of this condition?

options.label: C
options.text: Wait for resolution till 6 months of age

options.label: D
options.text: Wait for resolution till 2 years of age

questions.correct_answer: D. Wait for resolution till 2 years of age
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Wait for resolution till 2 years of age

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In congenital hydrocele, wait for resolution till 2 years. If the hydrocele persists beyond this age or if any complications arise, surgical intervention can be reconsidered.
  • ➤ In congenital hydrocele, wait for resolution till 2 years. If the hydrocele persists beyond this age or if any complications arise, surgical intervention can be reconsidered.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 8 weeks gestation presents for her first prenatal visit. She reports mild anemia, and further testing reveals that she has beta thalassemia minor. Her husband’s screening also shows that he is a carrier for the beta thalassemia trait. Which investigation would be the next appropriate step to assess the genetic status of the fetus?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases where both parents are carriers of beta thalassemia, chorionic villous sampling (CVS) between 10 and 13 weeks of gestation is recommended to determine the fetal genotype. This test provides early diagnostic information about the risk of the fetus having beta thalassemia major.
  • ➤ In cases where both parents are carriers of beta thalassemia, chorionic villous sampling (CVS) between 10 and 13 weeks of gestation is recommended to determine the fetal genotype.

questions.text: Which factor is likely responsible for the violation of Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium in a population?

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the pediatric cardiology clinic with a history of cyanosis, difficulty breathing during exertion, and episodes of "tet spells". questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with complaints of persistent throat discomfort and a sensation of something being stuck in his throat. questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

These findings can mimic a foreign body but are typically normal age-related changes. Recognizing this can prevent unnecessary diagnostic or therapeutic procedures, as elastic cartilage, unlike hyaline cartilage, does not undergo ossification.

questions.text: An 18-month-old female child is brought to the hospital due to recurrent episodes of hypoglycemia. questions.text: A 34-year-old woman at 31 weeks of gestation comes to the emergency department with sudden abdominal pain that has lasted for 2 hours. Her blood pressure is recorded at 160/100 mmHg. On examination, she appears pale, and the uterus measures larger than expected at 36 weeks of size and is notably tender to palpation. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 68-year-old postmenopausal woman with severe osteoporosis has been prescribed a medication that stimulates bone formation. The medication is administered once daily via subcutaneous injection, and her doctor instructs her to rotate the injection sites. Which of the following is a serious adverse effect associated with this medication that limits its duration of use?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Osteosarcoma

  • ➤ Educational Objective

  • ➤ Teriparatide is limited to a maximum of 2 years of use due to the potential risk of osteosarcoma, particularly in patients with predisposing conditions.

questions.text: A data analyst is examining the distribution of income levels within a specific population and notes that the distribution is positively skewed due to a few very high income values. Which statistical measure is most likely to be overestimated in this positively skewed dataset?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Mean

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In positively skewed distributions, the mean is disproportionately affected by outliers and can give an overestimated sense of the dataset’s central tendency.
  • ➤ In positively skewed distributions, the mean is disproportionately affected by outliers and can give an overestimated sense of the dataset’s central tendency.

questions.text: All of the following are correct statements regarding Prader-Willi syndrome except:

options.label: A
options.text: Prader-Willi syndrome is caused by a deletion on the paternal chromosome 15.

options.label: B
options.text: It is characterized by childhood obesity and hypotonia.

options.label: C
options.text: Prader-Willi syndrome typically presents with precocious puberty.

options.label: D
options.text: Patients with Prader-Willi syndrome often have delayed puberty and growth failure.

questions.correct_answer: C. Prader-Willi syndrome typically presents with precocious puberty.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by a genetic deletion on the paternal chromosome 15, leading to features such as hypotonia, childhood obesity, growth failure, delayed puberty, and behavioral problems. It does not present with precocious puberty; rather, puberty is typically delayed.
  • ➤ Prader-Willi syndrome is characterized by a genetic deletion on the paternal chromosome 15, leading to features such as hypotonia, childhood obesity, growth failure, delayed puberty, and behavioral problems.

questions.text: A phenotypically female child with ambiguous genitalia and clitoromegaly is brought to the clinic. On examination, she is found to have hypertension. A karyotype analysis is as given below. Based on this clinical presentation, what is the most likely enzyme deficiency in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In a 46, XY patient presenting with ambiguous genitalia, hypertension, and features of undervirilization, 17,20 lyase (or 17-hydroxylase) deficiency is the most likely diagnosis. This enzyme deficiency leads to reduced androgen production (causing undervirilization) and increased mineralocorticoid activity (resulting in hypertension).
  • ➤ In a 46, XY patient presenting with ambiguous genitalia, hypertension, and features of undervirilization, 17,20 lyase (or 17-hydroxylase) deficiency is the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department with 5-days history of fever and productive cough. He reports difficulty breathing and right-sided chest pain. On physical examination, his temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), and auscultation reveals crepitations on the right side. The chest X-ray is shown below. What is the correct finding?

options.label: A
options.text: Apical segment of right lower lobe consolidation

options.label: C
options.text: Posterior segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Right middle lobe consolidation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Right middle lobe consolidation is indicative of pneumonia, characterized by symptoms such as fever, productive cough, and crepitations, confirmed by a chest X-ray showing localized opacity in the right middle lobe.
  • ➤ Right middle lobe consolidation is indicative of pneumonia, characterized by symptoms such as fever, productive cough, and crepitations, confirmed by a chest X-ray showing localized opacity in the right middle lobe.

questions.text: A 51-year-old female presents with pain, tingling, and numbness over the upper thigh. Upon examination, the neurologist identifies the condition as meralgia paresthetica. Which of the following statements is true about the nerve responsible for this condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Emerges from the Medial Border of Psoas Major

options.label: D
options.text: The Anterior Branch of this nerve contributes to Patellar Plexus

questions.correct_answer: D. The Anterior Branch of this nerve contributes to Patellar Plexus
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral femoral cutaneous nerve, responsible for meralgia paresthetica, arises from the lumbar plexus (L2-L3) and the anterior branch of this nerve contributes to the patellar plexus, providing sensory innervation to the anterolateral thigh and around the patellar area.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of chronic diarrhea and weight loss is undergoing evaluation for possible celiac disease. Laboratory results show positive serology for celiac-specific antibodies. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding celiac disease?

options.label: A
options.text: Celiac disease is associated with HLA DQ6.

options.label: C
options.text: Marsh criteria are used for diagnosis.

options.label: D
options.text: IgA tissue transglutaminase antibodies are commonly found.

questions.correct_answer: A. Celiac disease is associated with HLA DQ6.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Celiac disease is associated with HLA DQ6.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease is strongly associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 alleles, not HLA-DQ6.
  • ➤ Celiac disease is strongly associated with HLA-DQ2 and HLA-DQ8 alleles, not HLA-DQ6.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to the emergency department with joint pain, dizziness, and skin rash after returning from a diving trip. He reports that he surfaced rapidly after a deep dive. His symptoms began shortly after he left the water. Physical examination reveals a patchy rash and tenderness in multiple joints. Based on his history, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dysbarism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dysbarism refers to a group of conditions caused by changes in ambient pressure, such as decompression sickness , which occurs after a rapid ascent from a deep dive. Symptoms may include joint pain, rash, dizziness, and fatigue due to nitrogen bubble formation in the blood.
  • ➤ Dysbarism refers to a group of conditions caused by changes in ambient pressure, such as decompression sickness , which occurs after a rapid ascent from a deep dive. Symptoms may include joint pain, rash, dizziness, and fatigue due to nitrogen bubble formation in the blood.
  • ➤ Dysbarism
  • ➤ decompression sickness

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents with generalized lymphadenopathy and significant weight loss over the past 3 months. A biopsy of a lymph node is performed, and the histological image is given below. Immunohistochemical staining is positive for CD30. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL) is a T-cell lymphoma that is positive for CD30 and characterized by large, pleomorphic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei (Hallmark cells).
  • ➤ Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL) is a T-cell lymphoma that is positive for CD30 and characterized by large, pleomorphic cells with horseshoe-shaped nuclei (Hallmark cells).

questions.text: A 66-year-old man is being evaluated for syncope. Holter monitoring reveals intermittent sinus pauses suggestive of dysfunction in the cardiac pacemaker cells. The pacemaker cells contain unique ion channels that contribute to their automaticity. Two statements are presented about these channels: Statement A : The f (funny) channels are present in cardiac pacemaker cells. Statement B : The f (funny) channels become activated after depolarization, leading to the action potential. Which of the following is correct regarding these statements?

options.label: A
options.text: Statement A is true, and Statement B is false

options.label: B
options.text: Statement A is false, and Statement B is true

options.label: C
options.text: Both Statement A and Statement B are true

options.label: D
options.text: Both Statement A and Statement B are false

questions.correct_answer: A. Statement A is true, and Statement B is false
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Statement A is true, and Statement B is false

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The funny (f) channels in cardiac pacemaker cells are activated by hyperpolarization, allowing slow inward sodium currents that lead to gradual depolarization and automaticity.
  • ➤ The funny (f) channels in cardiac pacemaker cells are activated by hyperpolarization, allowing slow inward sodium currents that lead to gradual depolarization and automaticity.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents after he experienced excessive bleeding following a minor fall. The parents report that the boy often bruises easily and has prolonged bleeding after minor injuries or dental procedures. He has no significant family history of bleeding disorders, but his maternal uncle has similar symptoms. Laboratory tests show an increased partial thromboplastin time (PTT) with normal prothrombin time (PT). What could be the probable mode of inheritance of this clinical condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) XLR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency in clotting factor VIII.
  • ➤ Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency in clotting factor VIII.

questions.text: Biochemical mechanisms of drug resistance are shown in the given image. The efflux mechanism (E) is a major mode of bacterial resistance against which of the following antibiotics?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Tetracyclines

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Efflux pumps are a primary mechanism of bacterial resistance to tetracyclines, actively transporting the drug out of the cell to reduce its efficacy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old primigravida in early labor arrives at the emergency department. She has regular, adequate uterine contractions, and a recent rupture of membranes. On vaginal examination, her pelvis is gynecoid, and the fetus is in the right occipito-posterior (ROP) position with the vertex presenting. What is the most appropriate management plan for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A fetus in the occipito-posterior position with adequate contractions and a favorable pelvic type (gynecoid) can often achieve a normal vaginal delivery without immediate intervention.
  • ➤ A fetus in the occipito-posterior position with adequate contractions and a favorable pelvic type (gynecoid) can often achieve a normal vaginal delivery without immediate intervention.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with a high spiking fever, a salmon-colored maculopapular rash, and symmetric arthritis involving the wrists and knees. She has also experienced significant fatigue and a sore throat over the past few weeks. Laboratory results reveal an elevated ESR (80 mm/hr), an elevated C-reactive protein (CRP). Which of the following will be markedly elevated, given the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ferritin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Markedly elevated ferritin is a distinguishing feature of Adult-Onset Still’s Disease and serves as an important diagnostic clue. It helps differentiate AOSD from other systemic inflammatory diseases like rheumatoid arthritis or lupus.

questions.text: A 55-year-old postmenopausal woman, presented to the OPD with back pain. Initial screening shows serum calcium levels of 11.7mg%, Vit. D is 55 ng/ml and elevated PTH. What might be the most common cause of such clinical manifestations?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Parathyroid Adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Elevated serum calcium and PTH with normal Vitamin D levels are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism, most commonly caused by a parathyroid adenoma. Recognizing this pattern helps in identifying the underlying cause and differentiating it from other causes of hypercalcemia.
  • ➤ Elevated serum calcium and PTH with normal Vitamin D levels are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism, most commonly caused by a parathyroid adenoma.
  • ➤ Recognizing this pattern helps in identifying the underlying cause and differentiating it from other causes of hypercalcemia.

questions.text: A 52-year-old patient presents with sensory loss along the medial side of the leg and foot after undergoing surgery for varicose veins. Based on this sensory deficit, which nerve is most likely to have been injured during the procedure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Saphenous nerve

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The saphenous nerve is responsible for sensory innervation of the medial aspect of the leg and foot. It can be injured during varicose vein surgery, leading to sensory loss in its distribution area.

questions.text: A patient sustained an injury to the right brow after a fall from a scooter and now presents with sudden loss of vision in the right eye. Examination reveals an absent direct light reflex in the right pupil but a normal consensual light reflex. The fundus appears normal. What is the treatment of choice for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Intensive intravenous corticosteroids as prescribed for spinal injuries, to be started within six hours

options.label: B
options.text: Pulse methylprednisolone 250 mg four times daily for three days

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Emergency optic canal decompression

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of acute optic nerve compression with sudden vision loss following trauma, emergency optic canal decompression is the treatment of choice to prevent permanent optic nerve damage and potentially restore vision.
  • ➤ In cases of acute optic nerve compression with sudden vision loss following trauma, emergency optic canal decompression is the treatment of choice to prevent permanent optic nerve damage and potentially restore vision.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is not typically used for neuromuscular monitoring?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neuromuscular monitoring requires a motor nerve to stimulate a muscle response, which helps assess the degree of muscle relaxation or recovery from neuromuscular blockade. The posterior tibial, facial, and ulnar nerves are commonly used because they innervate muscles, whereas the saphenous nerve is purely sensory and unsuitable for neuromuscular monitoring.
  • ➤ Neuromuscular monitoring requires a motor nerve to stimulate a muscle response, which helps assess the degree of muscle relaxation or recovery from neuromuscular blockade.
  • ➤ The posterior tibial, facial, and ulnar nerves are commonly used because they innervate muscles, whereas the saphenous nerve is purely sensory and unsuitable for neuromuscular monitoring.

questions.text: During the process of protein synthesis, the factor eEF-2 induces the hydrolysis of GTP. The energy of this hydrolysis is coupled to which of the following?

options.label: A
options.text: Amino acid activation by attachment to a tRNA

options.label: B
options.text: Correct alignment of the mRNA on the 40S ribosome

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Translocation of the ribosome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The elongation factor eEF-2 utilizes the energy from GTP hydrolysis to facilitate ribosome translocation , a critical step in the elongation phase of protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a five-day history of high fever, severe headache, muscle aches, and a dry cough. She mentions recently returning from a hiking trip in a forested area known for tick and mite activity. On examination, her temperature is 39.2°C (102.6°F), and there is a 1-cm blackened lesion with a surrounding red rim on her left thigh. She also has tender lymphadenopathy near the lesion site and mild crackles on lung auscultation. Laboratory studies reveal a normal white blood cell count and elevated liver enzymes. A chest X-ray shows diffuse interstitial infiltrates. Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Oral doxycycline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For rickettsial infections such as scrub typhus, which present with fever, eschar, and potential atypical pneumonia, doxycycline is the most effective initial treatment.
  • ➤ For rickettsial infections such as scrub typhus, which present with fever, eschar, and potential atypical pneumonia, doxycycline is the most effective initial treatment.

questions.text: A 29-year-old pregnant woman, underwent routine investigations that revealed a VDRL test positive at a 1:16 titer, with confirmatory TPHA also positive. She received adequate treatment with injection benzathine penicillin. Following this maternal treatment, what is the next appropriate management step for her newborn?

options.label: A
options.text: Perform serum VDRL of the baby

options.label: C
options.text: Perform CSF VDRL of the baby

options.label: D
options.text: Give injection aqueous penicillin to baby

questions.correct_answer: A. Perform serum VDRL of the baby
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Perform serum VDRL of the baby

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a mother is treated for syphilis during pregnancy, a serum VDRL test is essential for the newborn to determine possible congenital syphilis. A comparative titer assessment helps guide further intervention or the need for additional testing like CSF VDRL.
  • ➤ serum VDRL

questions.text: A 50-year-old rice farmer from northern Australia presents with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, weight loss, and productive cough. He reports generalized body aches and night sweats. Physical examination reveals mild hepatomegaly and tenderness in the right upper quadrant. Laboratory findings: WBC count: 14,500/mm³ Haemoglobin: 11.8 g/dL Platelets: 170,000/mm³ Blood cultures: Positive for a Gram-negative bacillus Imaging: Chest X-ray: Multiple nodular infiltrates and cavitary lesions in both lungs. Abdominal CT: Liver and spleen show multiple small hypodense lesions consistent with abscesses. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Burkholderia pseudomallei

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Melioidosis caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei should be suspected in patients with abscesses in multiple organs, especially in endemic regions and with occupational exposure to soil or water. Disseminated disease requires aggressive antibiotic therapy with ceftazidime or meropenem for the acute phase, followed by oral eradication therapy with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with fatigue, shortness of breath, and decreased urine output. Three weeks ago, she had a sore throat. She reports a history of chronic constipation. On physical examination: Blood pressure: 150/100 mm Hg Conjunctival pallor and bilateral pitting pedal edema are noted. There is tenderness to palpation over the lumbar spine and right 8th rib. Laboratory findings: Calcium: Elevated Hemoglobin: 9.8 g/dL Urine dipstick: Negative for blood and protein Serum creatinine: Elevated Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP): M-spike detected Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

options.label: A
options.text: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis with immune complex deposition

options.label: B
options.text: Renal deposition of immunoglobulin light chains

options.label: C
options.text: Renal deposition of AL amyloid fibrils

options.label: D
options.text: Hypercalcemia from a primary parathyroid adenoma

questions.correct_answer: B. Renal deposition of immunoglobulin light chains
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Renal deposition of immunoglobulin light chains

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This case demonstrates the importance of recognizing the classic features of multiple myeloma , particularly when renal dysfunction and hypercalcemia are present with an M-spike and rouleaux formation.

questions.text: The commonest cause of stiffness in hand injuries is:

options.label: C
options.text: Failure to use splintage in safety position

questions.correct_answer: C. Failure to use splintage in safety position
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Failure to use splintage in safety position

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The safety position is critical for preventing joint contractures, tendon shortening, and muscle atrophy during the healing phase after a hand injury. Failing to use this position or splint the hand properly is the most common cause of long-term stiffness in hand injuries.
  • ➤ The safety position is critical for preventing joint contractures, tendon shortening, and muscle atrophy during the healing phase after a hand injury.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man with a history of hypertension presents to the emergency department with palpitations and shortness of breath. His ECG shows an irregularly irregular rhythm and absence of P waves, consistent with atrial fibrillation. His ventricular rate is 140 beats per minute. The physician decides to initiate rate control. Which of the following drugs would be most appropriate to manage his heart rate in the context of atrial fibrillation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diltiazem

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For rate control in atrial fibrillation, calcium channel blockers (e.g., diltiazem), beta blockers, or digoxin are effective choices, while adenosine is ineffective for atrial fibrillation and is used only for PSVT.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with foul-smelling, bloody vaginal discharge mixed with mucous. Physical examination reveals a necrotic lesion on the cervix with lateral extension into the parametrium. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In locally advanced cervical cancer with parametrial involvement, chemoradiation is the treatment of choice to effectively manage locoregional disease and improve survival outcomes.
  • ➤ In locally advanced cervical cancer with parametrial involvement, chemoradiation is the treatment of choice to effectively manage locoregional disease and improve survival outcomes.

questions.text: Both Staphylococcus epidermidis and Escherichia coli were simultaneously grown on a culture medium in a lab. After overnight incubation, only E. coli flourished while S. epidermidis did not grow. What is the possible reason for this observation? Temperature of growth was set incorrectly Culture medium was selective E. coli produced colicin that inhibited S. epidermidis growth Gram-positive bacteria have a longer generation time Culture medium was differential
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2 only

  • ➤ The use of selective media can inhibit the growth of certain bacteria (e.g., Gram-positive organisms) while promoting the growth of others, such as E. coli (Gram-negative bacteria).

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with a 10-year history of systemic sclerosis presents with worsening shortness of breath, fatigue, and palpitations. On examination, she has a narrow split S2, elevated JVP, and bilaterally diminished breath sounds at the lung bases. Echocardiography estimates the pulmonary artery pressure at 45 mmHg, and pulmonary function tests reveal a restrictive pattern with reduced DLCO. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial therapy for managing her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Endothelin receptor antagonists

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Endothelin receptor antagonists are the first-line treatment for pulmonary hypertension in systemic sclerosis, as they effectively target the underlying pathophysiology of pulmonary vascular remodeling. In contrast, treatments like prostacyclin therapy and calcium channel blockers are generally reserved for more severe or specific cases.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with delusions that his thoughts are being broadcast on the radio, along with episodes of uncontrollable laughter without any emotional context. He has progressive cognitive decline and ataxia. EEG shows periodic sharp wave complexes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonic jerks, seizures and cerebellar ataxia. EEG usually shows periodic sharp wave complexes with slow background.
  • ➤ Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease is characterized by rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonic jerks, seizures and cerebellar ataxia. EEG usually shows periodic sharp wave complexes with slow background.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with developmental delay, growth failure, and distinctive coarse facial features. Laboratory findings show elevated lysosomal enzymes in the plasma, suggesting impaired lysosomal function. The condition is diagnosed as I-cell disease. Deficiency in which phosphorylating enzyme leads to the lack of which critical recognition marker responsible for lysosomal targeting in this disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Mannose 6-phosphate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In I-cell disease , a deficiency in N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase prevents the formation of mannose 6-phosphate (M6P) , a recognition marker necessary for the targeting of lysosomal enzymes. This lack of M6P tagging leads to the misdirection of lysosomal enzymes into the extracellular space, causing lysosomal dysfunction and cellular waste accumulation.
  • ➤ In I-cell disease , a deficiency in N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase prevents the formation of mannose 6-phosphate (M6P) , a recognition marker necessary for the targeting of lysosomal enzymes.
  • ➤ I-cell disease
  • ➤ N-acetylglucosamine-1-phosphotransferase
  • ➤ mannose 6-phosphate (M6P)
  • ➤ This lack of M6P tagging leads to the misdirection of lysosomal enzymes into the extracellular space, causing lysosomal dysfunction and cellular waste accumulation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a history of cholecystectomy presents with intermittent right upper quadrant pain and nausea for the past 2 weeks. Physical examination reveals mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant without guarding or rebound. Laboratory tests show: Total bilirubin: 1.2 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase: 190 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase (AST): 45 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (ALT): 50 U/L An abdominal CT scan is shown in image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Gallstone ileus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pneumobilia, when identified on imaging, should prompt evaluation for gallstone ileus, especially in patients with abdominal pain and a history of cholecystectomy or biliary disease.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents with progressive lower extremity weakness, severe back pain, and urinary incontinence over the past week. He also reports difficulty maintaining an erection. His medical history includes a herpes zoster infection 5 months ago, which resolved without complications. Physical examination reveals: Bilateral lower extremity motor weakness (grade 2/5) Loss of pinprick and vibration sensation below the T8 level Absent bulbocavernosus reflex Laboratory findings: ESR: Elevated CSF analysis: Mildly elevated protein, lymphocytic pleocytosis, negative oligoclonal bands Spine MRI shows diffuse spinal cord swelling with hyperintense lesions involving more than two-thirds of the cross-sectional area of the cord, extending over multiple vertebral levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Transverse myelitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transverse myelitis should be considered in patients with rapidly progressive motor, sensory, and autonomic dysfunction, particularly after a viral infection. MRI findings of longitudinally extensive spinal cord lesions are a hallmark feature. Early recognition and treatment with corticosteroids or immunotherapy are crucial.

questions.text: Which of the following structures primarily divides the liver into its anatomical segments under Couinaud classification?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Couinaud classification system uses the distribution of the portal vein branches to anatomically divide the liver into segments, which is essential for understanding liver anatomy, especially in the context of surgical planning and hepatic resections.
  • ➤ The Couinaud classification system uses the distribution of the portal vein branches to anatomically divide the liver into segments, which is essential for understanding liver anatomy, especially in the context of surgical planning and hepatic resections.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presents with a history of intermittent dysphagia to solid foods and occasional episodes of food impaction. He has no weight loss, chest pain, or heartburn. His symptoms have been gradually worsening over the past year. He has a history of seasonal allergies and eczema. Upper endoscopy image is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Eosinophilic esophagitis

questions.text: Which of the following is an absolute contraindication for spinal anesthesia?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Absolute contraindications for spinal anesthesia are conditions where the risks of the procedure outweigh any potential benefits. These include patient refusal, infection at the injection site, increased intracranial pressure, allergy to anesthetic drugs, coagulopathy or bleeding disorders, and severe hypovolemia. Recognizing these contraindications is crucial to ensure patient safety and appropriate anesthesia management.
  • ➤ Absolute contraindications for spinal anesthesia are conditions where the risks of the procedure outweigh any potential benefits.
  • ➤ These include patient refusal, infection at the injection site, increased intracranial pressure, allergy to anesthetic drugs, coagulopathy or bleeding disorders, and severe hypovolemia.
  • ➤ Recognizing these contraindications is crucial to ensure patient safety and appropriate anesthesia management.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a 3-week history of fever, unresponsive to antibiotics and anti-malarials. He also has abdominal distension, and the rk39 dipstick test is positive. What is the most appropriate next management step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Amphotericin B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A positive rk39 dipstick test along with prolonged fever and abdominal symptoms strongly suggests visceral leishmaniasis. The preferred treatment for this condition is Amphotericin B, particularly in cases where the disease does not respond to standard treatments for common febrile illnesses.
  • ➤ A positive rk39 dipstick test along with prolonged fever and abdominal symptoms strongly suggests visceral leishmaniasis.
  • ➤ The preferred treatment for this condition is Amphotericin B, particularly in cases where the disease does not respond to standard treatments for common febrile illnesses.

questions.text: A researcher is studying the effects of various drugs on cellular signal transduction pathways. Which of the following drugs is most likely to utilize the signaling mechanism illustrated?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Insulin

questions.text: A 52-year-old male presents with a progressive onset of involuntary movements, changes in personality, and gradual cognitive decline. He mentions that his father exhibited similar symptoms and passed away in his 50s. A brain MRI is performed, showing characteristic findings. Based on the clinical presentation and MRI results, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Huntington’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Huntington’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, marked by progressive chorea, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms. MRI findings typically include atrophy of the caudate and putamen, leading to enlarged lateral ventricles.
  • ➤ Huntington’s disease is a neurodegenerative disorder with an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern, marked by progressive chorea, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms.
  • ➤ MRI findings typically include atrophy of the caudate and putamen, leading to enlarged lateral ventricles.

questions.text: A junior resident is studying virus structures for her thesis and notes that certain viruses possess a lipid envelope, which plays a key role in viral entry into host cells. Which of the following viruses is known to have a lipid envelope?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpesviruses are enveloped viruses, unlike reoviruses and picornaviruses, which lack a lipid envelope.
  • ➤ Herpesviruses are enveloped viruses, unlike reoviruses and picornaviruses, which lack a lipid envelope.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents with symptoms of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) eight months after a previous abortion. Laboratory results reveal an elevated hCG level of 120,000 mIU/mL. X-ray findings indicate metastatic disease in liver. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For patients with high-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) with metastasis and elevated hCG levels, multi-agent chemotherapy (e.g., EMA-CO) is the most appropriate treatment approach to improve survival and achieve remission.
  • ➤ For patients with high-risk gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) with metastasis and elevated hCG levels, multi-agent chemotherapy (e.g., EMA-CO) is the most appropriate treatment approach to improve survival and achieve remission.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of extensive small bowel resection due to mesenteric ischemia presents with chronic diarrhea, weight loss, and fatigue. She has been managing her symptoms with oral rehydration solutions and dietary modifications. Despite these measures, she continues to experience malabsorption and progressive weight loss. Laboratory studies reveal hypoalbuminemia, vitamin B12 deficiency, and low iron levels. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacologic therapy to improve intestinal adaptation and nutrient absorption in this patient with short bowel syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Teduglutide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Teduglutide is the treatment of choice in patients with short bowel syndrome who experience severe malabsorption, as it promotes intestinal adaptation and improves nutrient absorption, potentially reducing dependency on parenteral nutrition.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman with a history of acid reflux begins taking an over-the-counter antacid. After a few days, she notices an increase in bowel movements and occasional loose stools. Which of the following components in her antacid is most likely causing this gastrointestinal side effect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Magnesium hydroxide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Magnesium hydroxide in antacids can lead to diarrhea, whereas calcium and aluminium based antacids are more likely to cause constipation.
  • ➤ Magnesium hydroxide in antacids can lead to diarrhea, whereas calcium and aluminium based antacids are more likely to cause constipation.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents with jaundice, pruritus, and weight loss. Imaging studies reveal a mass at the hepatic hilum involving the bifurcation of the right and left hepatic bile ducts. Which of the following best describes this type of tumor?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Klatskin tumors, or hilar cholangiocarcinomas, are nodular cholangiocarcinomas located at the hepatic hilum, specifically at the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts. They present with obstructive jaundice due to bile duct obstruction and are challenging to manage surgically due to their anatomical location.
  • ➤ Klatskin tumors, or hilar cholangiocarcinomas, are nodular cholangiocarcinomas located at the hepatic hilum, specifically at the confluence of the right and left hepatic ducts.
  • ➤ They present with obstructive jaundice due to bile duct obstruction and are challenging to manage surgically due to their anatomical location.

questions.text: A public health researcher aims to investigate the cause-effect relationship between physical activity levels and the development of cardiovascular diseases over time. questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of fatigue, unintentional weight loss, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath. He also complains of nasal congestion, occasional epistaxis, and arthralgia. On examination, there is a saddle-nose deformity, bilateral crackles on chest auscultation, and lower limb edema. Chest CT is shown below. Laboratory findings are as follows: Hemoglobin: 9.8 g/dL Platelets: 230,000/µL Creatinine: 3.4 mg/dL Urinalysis: Hematuria, RBC casts, proteinuria (2.5 g/day) anti-proteinase 3 antibodies: Positive ESR: 80 Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) is a multisystem vasculitis characterized by respiratory tract involvement (e.g., cavitary lesions, epistaxis, saddle-nose deformity) and pauci-immune glomerulonephritis (e.g., RBC casts, hematuria, and proteinuria), with c-ANCA positivity being a hallmark diagnostic feature.

questions.text: The plate shown depicts colonies of Haemophilus influenzae growing in proximity to a streak of Staphylococcus on blood agar. Which of the following factors is responsible for this growth phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) V factor

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The satellitism phenomenon observed in Haemophilus influenzae cultures on blood agar is due to V factor (NAD), which is released by adjacent bacterial colonies, enabling H. influenzae growth in their vicinity.
  • ➤ The satellitism phenomenon observed in Haemophilus influenzae cultures on blood agar is due to V factor (NAD), which is released by adjacent bacterial colonies, enabling H. influenzae growth in their vicinity.
  • ➤ V factor

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with symptoms including irritability, depression, and anemia. Blood work indicates a deficiency in pyridoxine (vitamin B6). Which of the following enzymes is likely to have reduced catalytic activity as a result of this deficiency?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Alanine aminotransferase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is dependent on pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6, for its catalytic activity. Vitamin B6 deficiency impairs enzymes that rely on PLP, which disrupts amino acid metabolism and can lead to neurological and hematological symptoms.
  • ➤ Alanine aminotransferase (ALT) is dependent on pyridoxal phosphate (PLP), the active form of vitamin B6, for its catalytic activity.
  • ➤ Alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • ➤ Vitamin B6 deficiency impairs enzymes that rely on PLP, which disrupts amino acid metabolism and can lead to neurological and hematological symptoms.
